VOL. XXXII, No. 4

FRESHMAN TEAMS
ROUND INTO SHAPE
Twenty-five Candidates Report at
Football Practice
MORE TRACK MEN NEEDED
Baseball Players Start Working
Within Next Two Weeks.
Freshman athletic activities are
rapidly getting under way as froshsoph contests loom in the near future. The first year men seem as
anxious to remove their green ties
as they were in former seasons to
don more colorful neckwear.
Twenty-five promising candidates
have answered Coach Clayton's call
for freshman football men. Out of
this number the majority have had
some experience in prep school
ranks and it is expected that a fairly
good team will be whipped into
shape by the time of the opening
game. Clayton, who is coaching
the frosh, starred last year as an
end on the Varsity team. He was
a member of the Western Maryland
College eleven before coming to
Hopkins.

COTILLON BOARD
ELECTS CARROLL
At a meeting held last Monday in the Mechanical Engineering Building, John Carroll
was elected secretary-treasurer of the Cotillon Club to fill
the office left vacant by the
failure of Carey Thompson
to return to the University
this year.
The second of the Saturday
night dances will be held in the
Civil Engineering Building
tomorrow night, with the
Simpson - Morris Orchestra
furnishing the music. The
usual admission of one dollar
will be charged.

Sop/is Reelect Hall
As Class President

VARSITY CLUB MAY
ADOPT UNIFORM PIN
New Methods of Awarding Track
Letters to be Discussed at
Meeting.
Little opportunity has been afforded the Varsity Club to entertain visiting football teams thus far
this season, because of the fact that
only one of the scheduled games has
been played at home. Plans are
being made to entertain the Loyola
football team at tHe tea dance to be
given by the Athletic Association
following the Loyola-Hopkins game
a week from tomorrow. The policy of the Club is to arrange for
overnight entertainment of visiting
teams at the various fraternity
houses.

Call For Track Men

Coach Ridgely Edwards issued a
Special call last Tuesday for more
candidates for the freshman track
team, With the freshman-sophomore meet only about four and a
half weeks off, candidates are sorely
needed for all events. The dearth
of weight men and jumpers is especially noticeable.
Regular workouts are being held
Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays at 4.15 on the track at Homewood Field. Chances of a freshman victory over the sophs are
rather bright this year and a full
turnout is hoped for.
Baseball practice for members of
this year's freshman and sophomore
/lines will begin in about two weeks
in order to prepare
for the big game
between the rival classes. The later event is scheduled to take place
in about a month. An added incentive on the part of both classes to
administer a decisive drubbing to
the other should be the fact that
last year's contest ended in a dissatisfying tie when the game was
called on account of darkness.

PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 14, 1927

WHILE AWAY AUTUMNAL AFTERNOONS
What with the abolishment of
freshman paddling and African golf
and the advent of seminaries for
the new student, those more unfortunate among us, who have no little
sisters with dolls at home or no
little brothers with tiddle-de-winks
sets to borrow every evening for a
quiet hour or two after dinner, are
pretty hard hit to find some sort
of clean, wholesome amusement for
these long autumnal afternoons.
Mrs. Vanneman, noticing the
deplorable mental conditions and
bored expressions on the usually
radiant countenances of her pets, as
a result of these new-fangled regulations, held a consultation with her
chief dieticians recently and has
found, if we may judge from appearances, a most satisfactory remedy for this new form of ennui.
One day during the early part of
the week a large delivery truck
stopped in front of the Memorial
Dormitories and two negro porters

were seen to take a long, low, pine
box out and carry it up to the quadrangle and carefully deposit it outside of Mrs. Vanneman's door. The
odds ranged from 3 and 4 to 1 that
some one died, but when three
youths from the surveying department appeared on the scene with
full paraphernalia and beaming
faces the odds dropped to even
money that it was a pogo stick.
Finally after many mysterious
maneuvers, the surveyors opened
the box and started putting up little
box-shaped wires and pretty multicolored stakes.
Now it dawned on their bored
brains. The good Mrs. Vanneman
had bought her boys a croquet set
to help pass the long, dull autumn
afternoons.
But what is all the noise and excitement around the dorms? Certainly not one of those brutal old
fashioned class rushes. No, pardon us, the boys arc only very much
excited over this niost fascinating,
new game and wish to try a round
or two before theil: next seminary.

SENIOR PRESIDENT

BLUE JAYS PLAY
QUAKERSTOMORROW
Game With Pennsylvania Team
Should Be Stiff Battle

Ii

HAVERFORD TEAM STRONG
Quaker Team Has Six Veterans—
Morris and Ensworth Stars
AI

H. Ridgely Warfield Who Was Elected
President of the Senior Class
Yesterday.

Warfield Chosen
Senior President
McElfresh and Lawrence
Elected to Student
Council
At a well-attended meeting of the
senior class yesterday afternoon in
the C. E. Hall the election of class
officers for the ensuing year took
place. Those elected were the following: President, H. Ridgely
Warfield, Jr.; Vice-president, C.
Gardiier Malionee ; Secreiltry, Da‘Tid
Kaufman; Treasurer, Leonard Dalsemer ; Sergeant-at-arms, G. Maxwell Armour, Jr.; Delegates to the
Student Council, Jack Lawrence
and Charles McElfresh. The elections were the only business of the
meeting, and the polls were open
from the close of the assembly until
one o'clock.
Member of Council

The president of the senior class
is automatically, according to the
constitution of the Student Council, a memlier of the latter organization. This will be the third year
that Warfield has served on the
Council.
Because of the large number of
nominees for the various offices in
the freshman class, no man received
a majority of the votes cast. According to the constitution unanimously adopted by the class at its
first meeting, one must receive a
majority of the number of votes cast
to be elected. In case no man does
receive a majority, those two having
the highest number of votes shall
again be balloted upon. A class
meeting for this purpose will be
held in the C. L. Building, room 10,
on Tuesday at 12: 20.
NOTICE.
At the Cotillon Dance in
the Civil Engineering Hall,
Saturday, October 8, a white
flannel coat with fur collar
was taken from the Ladies'
Rest Room by mistake in exchange for a similar coat.
There was a Hutzler Brothers' tag inside the collar.
Any information leading
to the whereabouts of said
coat will be greatly appreciated. Please communicate
with Dal Smith or John Bledsoe or drop note in Postoffice
Box No. 912.

Hopkins rooters are looking forward with great anticipation to tomorrow's game with Haverford.
The opening game with Richmond
at Homewood did not throw a very
good light on the Jay eleven, but
the Syracuse encounter last Saturday proved conclusively that the
Hopkins team has many real possibilities. During the second half of
the game with the Orange team the
ball was continually in their territory and the Black and Blue team
had five chances to score, of which
one was seized upon by the alert
Houston, who was _substituted for
Captain 1Vialtonee after the latter
had injured his arm.
Quakers Make Good Showing

From the showing the Haverford
team made against the powerful aggregation of Amherst last Saturday,
the game tomorrow should be a stiff
one for Hopkins. George Darley,
assistant coach, who was sent as
scout to the Amherst-Haverford
game last week, is very positive in
his statements that the Quaker club
will be a hard nut to crack.
Amherst was held to a fourteenpoint score last Saturday and two
weeks ago Franklin and Marshall,
which held Penn to an 8-0 score,
was beaten 11 to 0 by the Haverford team.
Strader May Not Play

Dal Shader, first string center,
who was injured in the initial game
of the season, may be back in the
line-up, but it is doubtful if he will
play the entire game. Two former
Poly athletes, Powell and Boyd,
have been making good showings at
the pivot position and in the event
of Strader's not being able to start
one of these men will be substituted
for him.
A squad of about thirty men will
leave the Pennsylvania station Saturday morning and will return Saturday night. Quite a number of
fans will journey to Haverford to
see the game, which is the second
successive game away from home.
Many Regulars Back

The Quaker team will have six
regulars back this year, and most
of the other five regulars saw second-string service last season. In
the game against Amherst Morris
and Ensworth were towers of
strength on the defense; Morris at
right tackle proved a stumblingblock to many of the Amherst line
plays, while Ensworth, who was a
substitute back last year, did very
brilliant work in backing up the
line.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1927

2

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

YES AND NO

FOUNDED 1897

To the Yes and No Column—
I am on the trail of scandal; . . . Such scandal! Conspiracy in the high places! Or perhaps it is an accident. However,
a new college has appeared. No, not Hopkins; that may be a college later; at present we refer to St. John's, a hitherto unknown
institution which hides its light under the bushel of Annapolis (or
can Annapolis be referred to without flattery as an entire bushel?)
Anyway, since Johns Hopkins has become a rival of Oxford, this
Annapolis institution has, we repeat, appeared. Last year (its
first to the extent of our information), St. John's had a freshman
class of sixty-five men; this year, the entering students number
one hundred and thirty-five men. . . And such men! Perhaps a natural preference for the more somber requisite of black
ties figures in this increase; more probably, Hopkins' steady increase of tuition and decrease of . . . well, never mind—
perhaps these considerations changed the young minds of many
men who intended to come here; again, these potential Ph. D.'s
may have weighed courses under genuine instructors, at a cost
of two hundred and fifty dollars, against courses under graduate
students at four hundred per year. And then, there are courses
at St. John's, a fact of minor importance, perhaps, but still a fact,
which contrasts with the Hopkins undergraduate curriculum.

$2.00

THE A. A. BOARD
An apparently time-worn tradition at Hopkins is the system
of electing members of the A. A. Board, according to classes,
by the entire student body. Although athletes are usually the
men to be chosen, anyone at all may be nominated, and subsequently elected. Moreover, inexperienced men are sure to be
elected from the lower classes, regardless of whether they are
athletes or not. The make-up of the Board, it seems to us, is
highly illogical.
Instead of electing the Athletic Board early in May, we suggest
that membership be entirely automatic and that it be taken out of
the hands of the student body. It would be much more desirable
from many standpoints to have the Board made up of all the
captains and managers of varsity sports, with the possible addition
of two or three senior members of varsity teams. These two or
three members-at-large could be elected by the student body at the
same time that the president of the student council is elected, or
could be elected by the men who have won their letter in varsity
sports.
An inspection of the personnel of the 1927-28 Board will show
that the following men do not hold membership: The captains
of track, cross country, and swimming; the managers of lacrosse,
track and swimming. The track and swimming teams have no
representation on the Board whatsoever.
Inasmuch as the captains and managers are the men chosen by
the teams to lead them through the athletic season, these same
men should be the ones to direct the administrative policy of
University athletics. It seems ludicrous that three captains and
three managers should be excluded from the Board when men
who have never won the H are members.
The election of three members-at-large from the senior class
would allow experienced men to help in the administration of
athletics even though they might not be captains of teams.
The present system is entirely anomalous. Even though the
captains of track and lacrosse should be eligibile for election to the
A. A. Board, the Board election precedes the captaincy elections,
making it impossible to know who the captains will be until after
it is too late.
We suggest that this plan be submitted to the student body as
soon as possible and that the 1928-29 Board be elected under the
new system.

This St. John's College may quite possibly supplant the extinct
Johns Hopkins as the beloved and honored institution of Maryland. Undoubtedly, when student activities here are reduced to
stamp-collecting and chess, as they soon will be, men who ten
years ago might have upheld the honor of J. H. U. will be adding
glory to the name of St. John's. There may even be fraternities
in Annapolis.
As for the town itself, its appeal is attested by the recent migrations of our own freshmen and sophomore classes. Last year
these men, regretting their choice of an Alma Mater, could not
forbear an envious look at what might have been; so boisterous
was their enthusiasm, that quiet old Annapolis was moved to
alarm rather than to welcome. The Hopkins freshman class
of this year differ from their predecessors only in that they went
to Annapolis in time to get into St. John's.
It is a vivid contrast—this contrast of two universities, one
vigorous in its youth, the other lethargic and intensely dignified
in a premature middle-age; one sacrificing fine fraternity prospects for spectacled students oozing crude oil, the other offering
its poor but noble best and winning all of Baltimore's upright,
splendid young American manhood; one clinging to a remnant
of athletic prestige only through the valiant obstinacy of a lacrosse
team, the other building—building from the very bottom, a name
in athletic circles. It is a tragic contrast.
Perhaps there is no scandal. Perhaps it is an accident. * *
St. John's is getting rich.
Respectfully yours,
G. G.

Dr. French Resigns
As Debating Adviser
At a meeting of the Debating
Council last Tuesday, the resignation of Dr. John C. French, faculty
adviser, was accepted. Dr. French
has acted in the capacity of adviser
for a number of years, selecting
speakers for the various teams, advising and coaching with untiring
effort. His loss will be keenly felt.
Norman B. Gardiner presided at
the meeting which was called together for the purpose of taking
action on Dr. French's resignation
and also for the election of a new
president. This vacancy was caused
by the failure of J. Cary Thompson
to return to the university. The results of the election were as fol-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1927
SOY"

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Some of the University of Vermont sophomores are united in a
body called the Golden Key Society
for the purpose of punishing delinquent freshmen. Recently a number of yearlings who had not conformed to regulations were compelled to stand out in the cold
autumn evening while the Golden
Key held a meeting and then were
forced to enter the meeting room
and undergo a strenuous siege of
Paddling. Might not be such a bad
idea, sophs!
*

The budget system which is in
use at Hopkins to provide for student activities might well be adopted by several other colleges throughout the country judging from the
difficulties which other universities
are experiencing in financing student bands. Wake Forest College
has resorted to the expedient of requesting the student body to donate
funds to help the band while the
Lafayette band took up a collection
from the stands during the Rutgers
game.

Al last we have found another
college which imposes vivid green
ties on freshmen. The science frosh
at McGill University are required
to wear the odious neck-gear, but
McGill goes us one better in providing a garter as a companion for
their green ties. These garters (or
garter, as only one is required),
must be worn on the outside of the
trouser leg just below the knee.
Hopkins frosh may consider themselves lucky.

One of the haberdashers situated
near Rutgers donates a valuable
Piece of clothing each week to the
Rutgers student who guesses closest to the score of each Saturday's
game. How about it, merchant
princes?

The winner of the famous Collegiate Cab Contest which was held
some years ago at Hopkins may
now go and bow down abjectly before the student at the Polytechnic
Preparatory Day School of Brooklyn, who is using an old cement
mixer to ride to college. He claims
to have reached the campus once on
eleven crankings only.

Dean Scott H. Goodnight of Wisconsin University has issued a pamphlet in which he warns students
to beware of the six vices of loafing, smoking, profanity, gambling,
drinking and lewdness. Has anyone noticed any of the model young
men of Hopkins practicing any of
these evils?

South Dakota are financing a new
$250,000 stadium by a small tax on
cigarettes bought on the campus.
Judging by the butts scattered
around Gilman Hall, the Hopkins
A. A. would find this a profitable
way to raise funds.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1927

JUNIORS NOMINATE
CLASS OFFICERS

ACTIVITIES COUNCIL
TO HOLD MEETING
As soon as money is received from the Treasurer, the
Student Activities Council will
hold its first meeting of this
season. That will probably be
this week or the next, according to Osmar Steinwald, secretary of the Council.
Steinwald will preside over
the Council's affairs while
Charles McElfresh, president
of the Council, is recovering
from an operation of appendicitis.

Further Nominations and Elections to Take Place Today

HECHT SUBMITS REPORT
Hershey, Kegan and Wood Proposed for Presidency
Nomination of class officers was
the chief business transacted at the
first Junior Class meeting of the
year, held last Friday in the C. E.
Hall.
Three men were nominated for
the presidency — Hershey, Kegan
and R. Wood. Those proposed for
the position of secretary were Nice,
Banks, Shepherd, Campbell and
Stevenson. Hecht, Gordon and
Driver were the candidates for the
treasurer's post and Plummer and
Caplan for sergeant-at-arms. Due
to the poor attendance at this meeting and in accord with the ruling
made in the case of other classes,
Philip Nes., outgoing president of
the dass, announced that the nominations would be thrown open before the elections, which will take
place today at 12.30 in the C. E.
Hall.
Balance in Treasury

Following these nominations
Samuel Hecht, treasurer of the
class, announced that a balance of
$35.93 existed in the treasury. Last
year's receipts were $939.00, with
expenditures of $906.00. The surplus is less than had been planned,
because many Of the fines levied
upon the Sophs following the memorable "Battle of the Armory" were
paid out of the class funds.
A discussion then arose over the
desirability of having separate nominations for the office of vice-president. According to the constitution of the Class of '29, the vicepresident shall be the presidential
candidate with the second highest
number of votes. Further action on
this matter was deferred until the
next meeting.
Difficult to Amend

The question of an amendment
to the constitution to remedy the
difficulty which was caused last year
by the clause which states the number necessary to constitute a quorum was discussed. Although several suggestions were made, it was
decided to wait until the next meeting to finally settle this matter.
At the election of student council delegates for the Junior Class,
held last spring, Donald Hiss and
Hamilton Allen were chosen to represent their class.

Candidates Report
for Band Practice
Response to the appeal for candidates for the Hopkins Band was
quite up to expectations this year.
According to Secretary Schultheis,
about twenty-five men handed in
their names at a meeting held Monday afternoon. Most of last year's
men have returned to college and, in
addition, there are several musically inclined freshmen who have
signed up for Band practice.
The first rehearsal was held yesterday, and in the future rehearsals
will take place Monday and Thursday until further notice. In the
absence of Charles W. McElfresh,
the leader, Osmar P. Steinwald is
directing. As formerly, the band
will play at all games and at R. 0.
T. C. drills.
The University furnishes the musicians with instruments free of
charge. These may be obtained
from Sergeant Boyce by applying
to Steinwald for a permit. There
are openings for men who can play
almost any type of wind instrument
and all those who have had any ex1?erince-whattver are urged- to tryout.

Madison 5355

Night—Madison 1536

JONES CHEVROLET
SALES COMPANY

Business Staff Meeting Scheduled For
Today in Barn

Leonard Dalsemer announced
that the policy of the Hullabaloo this
this year would be somewhat different from that in the past. The size of
the book will be cut in order to assure quality without sacrificing any
essentials. It is interesting to note
that the Read-Taylor Co., printers
of last year's Hullabaloo, announced
that more volumes were printed of
this book than of any of the thirty
college year books which they publish.
Dalsemer said that he and assist
ant business manager Eldridge
would go to New York this weekend to complete photographic arrangements with the White Studios,
largest photographers for college
year books in this country. It is
planned to start photographing
about November 1.
A meeting of the business staff
of the Hullabaloo will be held today
at 12.30 in the Blue Jay office at
the Barn, Dalsemer added. All
candidates for the business staff of
this publication are expected to be
present. It is planned to start soliciting advertisements for the Hullabaloo the first of next week.

Dr. Voss Returns
Here for Research
It is interesting to note that Dr.
Vivian Voss has returned to the
University after an absence of ten
years. Dr. Voss received the degree of Master of Arts in 1916 and
that of Doctor of Philosophy in
1917 from this University.
Since then he has resided in several different countries. He took
an active part in the last war, after
which he became interested in South
Africa. Dr. Voss' position is that
of Senior Lecturer in Physics at the
Transvaal University College.
At present he is beginning a
year's research in the Physical Laboratory here, under Dr. Wood, after
which he will probably return to
South Africa.
Dr. Voss brought his wife with
him, and she will also spend the
winter here. The difference in seasons makes it possible for Dr. Voss
to come here, for the Transvaal
University College has just closed
for the summer vacation.

VOL. XXXII, No. 4

FRESHMAN TEAMS
ROUND INTO SHAPE
Twenty-five Candidates Report at
Football Practice
MORE TRACK MEN NEEDED
Baseball Players Start Working
Within Next Two Weeks.
Freshman athletic activities are
rapidly getting under way as froshsoph contests loom in the near future. The first year men seem as
anxious to remove their green ties
as they were in former seasons to
don more colorful neckwear.
Twenty-five promising candidates
have answered Coach Clayton's call
for freshman football men. Out of
this number the majority have had
some experience in prep school
ranks and it is expected that a fairly
good team will be whipped into
shape by the time of the opening
game. Clayton, who is coaching
the frosh, starred last year as an
end on the Varsity team. He was
a member of the Western Maryland
College eleven before coming to
Hopkins.

COTILLON BOARD
ELECTS CARROLL
At a meeting held last Monday in the Mechanical Engineering Building, John Carroll
was elected secretary-treasurer of the Cotillon Club to fill
the office left vacant by the
failure of Carey Thompson
to return to the University
this year.
The second of the Saturday
night dances will be held in the
Civil Engineering Building
tomorrow night, with the
Simpson - Morris Orchestra
furnishing the music. The
usual admission of one dollar
will be charged.

New Methods of Awarding Track
Letters to be Discussed at

this season, because of the fact that
only one of the scheduled games has
been played at home. Plans are
being made to entertain the Loyola
football team at tHe tea dance to be
given by the Athletic Association
following the Loyola-Hopkins game
a week from tomorrow. The policy of the Club is to arrange for
overnight entertainment of visiting
teams at the various fraternity
houses.

Call For Track Men

Coach Ridgely Edwards issued a
Special call last Tuesday for more
candidates for the freshman track
team, With the freshman-sophomore meet only about four and a
half weeks off, candidates are sorely
needed for all events. The dearth
of weight men and jumpers is especially noticeable.
Regular workouts are being held
Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays at 4.15 on the track at Homewood Field. Chances of a freshman victory over the sophs are
rather bright this year and a full
turnout is hoped for.
Baseball practice for members of
this year's freshman and sophomore
/lines will begin in about two weeks
in order to prepare
for the big game
between the rival classes. The later event is scheduled to take place
in about a month. An added incentive on the part of both classes to
administer a decisive drubbing to
the other should be the fact that
last year's contest ended in a dissatisfying tie when the game was
called on account of darkness.

PRICE 5 CENTS

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 14, 1927

WHILE AWAY AUTUMNAL AFTERNOONS
What with the abolishment of
freshman paddling and African golf
and the advent of seminaries for
the new student, those more unfortunate among us, who have no little
sisters with dolls at home or no
little brothers with tiddle-de-winks
sets to borrow every evening for a
quiet hour or two after dinner, are
pretty hard hit to find some sort
of clean, wholesome amusement for
these long autumnal afternoons.
Mrs. Vanneman, noticing the
deplorable mental conditions and
bored expressions on the usually
radiant countenances of her pets, as
a result of these new-fangled regulations, held a consultation with her
chief dieticians recently and has
found, if we may judge from appearances, a most satisfactory remedy for this new form of ennui.
One day during the early part of
the week a large delivery truck
stopped in front of the Memorial
Dormitories and two negro porters

were seen to take a long, low, pine
box out and carry it up to the quadrangle and carefully deposit it outside of Mrs. Vanneman's door. The
odds ranged from 3 and 4 to 1 that
some one died, but when three
youths from the surveying department appeared on the scene with
full paraphernalia and beaming
faces the odds dropped to even
money that it was a pogo stick.
Finally after many mysterious
maneuvers, the surveyors opened
the box and started putting up little
box-shaped wires and pretty multicolored stakes.
Now it dawned on their bored
brains. The good Mrs. Vanneman
had bought her boys a croquet set
to help pass the long, dull autumn
afternoons.
But what is all the noise and excitement around the dorms? Certainly not one of those brutal old
fashioned class rushes. No, pardon us, the boys arc only very much
excited over this niost fascinating,
new game and wish to try a round
or two before theil: next seminary.

BLUE JAYS PLAY
QUAKERSTOMORROW
Game With Pennsylvania Team

HAVERFORD TEAM STRONG
Quaker Team Has Six Veterans—
Morris and Ensworth Stars
AI

H. Ridgely Warfield Who Was Elected
President of the Senior Class
Yesterday.

Warfield Chosen
Senior President
McElfresh and Lawrence
Elected to Student
Council
At a well-attended meeting of the
senior class yesterday afternoon in
the C. E. Hall the election of class
officers for the ensuing year took
place. Those elected were the following: President, H. Ridgely
Warfield, Jr.; Vice-president, C.
Gardiier Malionee ; Secreiltry, Da‘Tid
Kaufman; Treasurer, Leonard Dalsemer ; Sergeant-at-arms, G. Maxwell Armour, Jr.; Delegates to the
Student Council, Jack Lawrence
and Charles McElfresh. The elections were the only business of the
meeting, and the polls were open
from the close of the assembly until
one o'clock.
Member of Council

The president of the senior class
is automatically, according to the
constitution of the Student Council, a memlier of the latter organization. This will be the third year
that Warfield has served on the
Council.
Because of the large number of
nominees for the various offices in
the freshman class, no man received
a majority of the votes cast. According to the constitution unanimously adopted by the class at its
first meeting, one must receive a
majority of the number of votes cast
to be elected. In case no man does
receive a majority, those two having
the highest number of votes shall
again be balloted upon. A class
meeting for this purpose will be
held in the C. L. Building, room 10,
on Tuesday at 12: 20.
NOTICE.
At the Cotillon Dance in
the Civil Engineering Hall,
Saturday, October 8, a white
flannel coat with fur collar
was taken from the Ladies'
Rest Room by mistake in exchange for a similar coat.
There was a Hutzler Brothers' tag inside the collar.
Any information leading
to the whereabouts of said
coat will be greatly appreciated. Please communicate
with Dal Smith or John Bledsoe or drop note in Postoffice
Box No. 912.

Hopkins rooters are looking forward with great anticipation to tomorrow's game with Haverford.
The opening game with Richmond
at Homewood did not throw a very
good light on the Jay eleven, but
the Syracuse encounter last Saturday proved conclusively that the
Hopkins team has many real possibilities. During the second half of
the game with the Orange team the
ball was continually in their territory and the Black and Blue team
had five chances to score, of which
one was seized upon by the alert
Houston, who was _substituted for
Captain 1Vialtonee after the latter
had injured his arm.
Quakers Make Good Showing

From the showing the Haverford
team made against the powerful aggregation of Amherst last Saturday,
the game tomorrow should be a stiff
one for Hopkins. George Darley,
assistant coach, who was sent as
scout to the Amherst-Haverford
game last week, is very positive in
his statements that the Quaker club
will be a hard nut to crack.
Amherst was held to a fourteenpoint score last Saturday and two
weeks ago Franklin and Marshall,
which held Penn to an 8-0 score,
was beaten 11 to 0 by the Haverford team.
Strader May Not Play

Dal Shader, first string center,
who was injured in the initial game
of the season, may be back in the
line-up, but it is doubtful if he will
play the entire game. Two former
Poly athletes, Powell and Boyd,
have been making good showings at
the pivot position and in the event
of Strader's not being able to start
one of these men will be substituted
for him.
A squad of about thirty men will
leave the Pennsylvania station Saturday morning and will return Saturday night. Quite a number of
fans will journey to Haverford to
see the game, which is the second
successive game away from home.
Many Regulars Back

The Quaker team will have six
regulars back this year, and most
of the other five regulars saw second-string service last season. In
the game against Amherst Morris
and Ensworth were towers of
strength on the defense; Morris at
right tackle proved a stumblingblock to many of the Amherst line
plays, while Ensworth, who was a
substitute back last year, did very
brilliant work in backing up the
line.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1927

2

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

YES AND NO

FOUNDED 1897

To the Yes and No Column—
I am on the trail of scandal; . . . Such scandal! Conspiracy in the high places! Or perhaps it is an accident. However,
a new college has appeared. No, not Hopkins; that may be a college later; at present we refer to St. John's, a hitherto unknown
institution which hides its light under the bushel of Annapolis (or
can Annapolis be referred to without flattery as an entire bushel?)
Anyway, since Johns Hopkins has become a rival of Oxford, this
Annapolis institution has, we repeat, appeared. Last year (its
first to the extent of our information), St. John's had a freshman
class of sixty-five men; this year, the entering students number
one hundred and thirty-five men. . . And such men! Perhaps a natural preference for the more somber requisite of black
ties figures in this increase; more probably, Hopkins' steady increase of tuition and decrease of . . . well, never mind—
perhaps these considerations changed the young minds of many
men who intended to come here; again, these potential Ph. D.'s
may have weighed courses under genuine instructors, at a cost
of two hundred and fifty dollars, against courses under graduate
students at four hundred per year. And then, there are courses
at St. John's, a fact of minor importance, perhaps, but still a fact,
which contrasts with the Hopkins undergraduate curriculum.

THE A. A. BOARD
An apparently time-worn tradition at Hopkins is the system
of electing members of the A. A. Board, according to classes,
by the entire student body. Although athletes are usually the
men to be chosen, anyone at all may be nominated, and subsequently elected. Moreover, inexperienced men are sure to be
elected from the lower classes, regardless of whether they are
athletes or not. The make-up of the Board, it seems to us, is
highly illogical.
Instead of electing the Athletic Board early in May, we suggest
that membership be entirely automatic and that it be taken out of
the hands of the student body. It would be much more desirable
from many standpoints to have the Board made up of all the
captains and managers of varsity sports, with the possible addition
of two or three senior members of varsity teams. These two or
three members-at-large could be elected by the student body at the
same time that the president of the student council is elected, or
could be elected by the men who have won their letter in varsity
sports.
An inspection of the personnel of the 1927-28 Board will show
that the following men do not hold membership: The captains
of track, cross country, and swimming; the managers of lacrosse,
track and swimming. The track and swimming teams have no
representation on the Board whatsoever.
Inasmuch as the captains and managers are the men chosen by
the teams to lead them through the athletic season, these same
men should be the ones to direct the administrative policy of
University athletics. It seems ludicrous that three captains and
three managers should be excluded from the Board when men
who have never won the H are members.
The election of three members-at-large from the senior class
would allow experienced men to help in the administration of
athletics even though they might not be captains of teams.
The present system is entirely anomalous. Even though the
captains of track and lacrosse should be eligibile for election to the
A. A. Board, the Board election precedes the captaincy elections,
making it impossible to know who the captains will be until after
it is too late.
We suggest that this plan be submitted to the student body as
soon as possible and that the 1928-29 Board be elected under the
new system.

This St. John's College may quite possibly supplant the extinct
Johns Hopkins as the beloved and honored institution of Maryland. Undoubtedly, when student activities here are reduced to
stamp-collecting and chess, as they soon will be, men who ten
years ago might have upheld the honor of J. H. U. will be adding
glory to the name of St. John's. There may even be fraternities
in Annapolis.
As for the town itself, its appeal is attested by the recent migrations of our own freshmen and sophomore classes. Last year
these men, regretting their choice of an Alma Mater, could not
forbear an envious look at what might have been; so boisterous
was their enthusiasm, that quiet old Annapolis was moved to
alarm rather than to welcome. The Hopkins freshman class
of this year differ from their predecessors only in that they went
to Annapolis in time to get into St. John's.
It is a vivid contrast—this contrast of two universities, one
vigorous in its youth, the other lethargic and intensely dignified
in a premature middle-age; one sacrificing fine fraternity prospects for spectacled students oozing crude oil, the other offering
its poor but noble best and winning all of Baltimore's upright,
splendid young American manhood; one clinging to a remnant
of athletic prestige only through the valiant obstinacy of a lacrosse
team, the other building—building from the very bottom, a name
in athletic circles. It is a tragic contrast.
Perhaps there is no scandal. Perhaps it is an accident. * *
St. John's is getting rich.
Respectfully yours,
G. G.

Dr. French Resigns
As Debating Adviser
At a meeting of the Debating
Council last Tuesday, the resignation of Dr. John C. French, faculty
adviser, was accepted. Dr. French
has acted in the capacity of adviser
for a number of years, selecting
speakers for the various teams, advising and coaching with untiring
effort. His loss will be keenly felt.
Norman B. Gardiner presided at
the meeting which was called together for the purpose of taking
action on Dr. French's resignation
and also for the election of a new
president. This vacancy was caused
by the failure of J. Cary Thompson
to return to the university. The results of the election were as fol-

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1927
SOY"

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Some of the University of Vermont sophomores are united in a
body called the Golden Key Society
for the purpose of punishing delinquent freshmen. Recently a number of yearlings who had not conformed to regulations were compelled to stand out in the cold
autumn evening while the Golden
Key held a meeting and then were
forced to enter the meeting room
and undergo a strenuous siege of
Paddling. Might not be such a bad
idea, sophs!

The budget system which is in
use at Hopkins to provide for student activities might well be adopted by several other colleges throughout the country judging from the
difficulties which other universities
are experiencing in financing student bands. Wake Forest College
has resorted to the expedient of requesting the student body to donate
funds to help the band while the
Lafayette band took up a collection
from the stands during the Rutgers
game.

Al last we have found another
college which imposes vivid green
ties on freshmen. The science frosh
at McGill University are required
to wear the odious neck-gear, but
McGill goes us one better in providing a garter as a companion for
their green ties. These garters (or
garter, as only one is required),
must be worn on the outside of the
trouser leg just below the knee.
Hopkins frosh may consider themselves lucky.

One of the haberdashers situated
near Rutgers donates a valuable
Piece of clothing each week to the
Rutgers student who guesses closest to the score of each Saturday's
game. How about it, merchant
princes?

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 14, 1927

JUNIORS NOMINATE
CLASS OFFICERS

ACTIVITIES COUNCIL
TO HOLD MEETING
As soon as money is received from the Treasurer, the
Student Activities Council will
hold its first meeting of this
season. That will probably be
this week or the next, according to Osmar Steinwald, secretary of the Council.
Steinwald will preside over
the Council's affairs while
Charles McElfresh, president
of the Council, is recovering
from an operation of appendicitis.

Further Nominations and Elections to Take Place Today

HECHT SUBMITS REPORT
Hershey, Kegan and Wood Proposed for Presidency
Nomination of class officers was
the chief business transacted at the
first Junior Class meeting of the
year, held last Friday in the C. E.
Hall.
Three men were nominated for
the presidency — Hershey, Kegan
and R. Wood. Those proposed for
the position of secretary were Nice,
Banks, Shepherd, Campbell and
Stevenson. Hecht, Gordon and
Driver were the candidates for the
treasurer's post and Plummer and
Caplan for sergeant-at-arms. Due
to the poor attendance at this meeting and in accord with the ruling
made in the case of other classes,
Philip Nes., outgoing president of
the dass, announced that the nominations would be thrown open before the elections, which will take
place today at 12.30 in the C. E.
Hall.
Balance in Treasury

Following these nominations
Samuel Hecht, treasurer of the
class, announced that a balance of
$35.93 existed in the treasury. Last
year's receipts were $939.00, with
expenditures of $906.00. The surplus is less than had been planned,
because many Of the fines levied
upon the Sophs following the memorable "Battle of the Armory" were
paid out of the class funds.
A discussion then arose over the
desirability of having separate nominations for the office of vice-president. According to the constitution of the Class of '29, the vicepresident shall be the presidential
candidate with the second highest
number of votes. Further action on
this matter was deferred until the
next meeting.
Difficult to Amend

The question of an amendment
to the constitution to remedy the
difficulty which was caused last year
by the clause which states the number necessary to constitute a quorum was discussed. Although several suggestions were made, it was
decided to wait until the next meeting to finally settle this matter.
At the election of student council delegates for the Junior Class,
held last spring, Donald Hiss and
Hamilton Allen were chosen to represent their class.

Candidates Report
for Band Practice
Response to the appeal for candidates for the Hopkins Band was
quite up to expectations this year.
According to Secretary Schultheis,
about twenty-five men handed in
their names at a meeting held Monday afternoon. Most of last year's
men have returned to college and, in
addition, there are several musically inclined freshmen who have
signed up for Band practice.
The first rehearsal was held yesterday, and in the future rehearsals
will take place Monday and Thursday until further notice. In the
absence of Charles W. McElfresh,
the leader, Osmar P. Steinwald is
directing. As formerly, the band
will play at all games and at R. 0.
T. C. drills.
The University furnishes the musicians with instruments free of
charge. These may be obtained
from Sergeant Boyce by applying
to Steinwald for a permit. There
are openings for men who can play
almost any type of wind instrument
and all those who have had any ex1?erince-whattver are urged- to tryout.

Madison 5355

Night—Madison 1536

JONES CHEVROLET
SALES COMPANY

Business Staff Meeting Scheduled For
Today in Barn

Leonard Dalsemer announced
that the policy of the Hullabaloo this
this year would be somewhat different from that in the past. The size of
the book will be cut in order to assure quality without sacrificing any
essentials. It is interesting to note
that the Read-Taylor Co., printers
of last year's Hullabaloo, announced
that more volumes were printed of
this book than of any of the thirty
college year books which they publish.
Dalsemer said that he and assist
ant business manager Eldridge
would go to New York this weekend to complete photographic arrangements with the White Studios,
largest photographers for college
year books in this country. It is
planned to start photographing
about November 1.
A meeting of the business staff
of the Hullabaloo will be held today
at 12.30 in the Blue Jay office at
the Barn, Dalsemer added. All
candidates for the business staff of
this publication are expected to be
present. It is planned to start soliciting advertisements for the Hullabaloo the first of next week.

Dr. Voss Returns
Here for Research
It is interesting to note that Dr.
Vivian Voss has returned to the
University after an absence of ten
years. Dr. Voss received the degree of Master of Arts in 1916 and
that of Doctor of Philosophy in
1917 from this University.
Since then he has resided in several different countries. He took
an active part in the last war, after
which he became interested in South
Africa. Dr. Voss' position is that
of Senior Lecturer in Physics at the
Transvaal University College.
At present he is beginning a
year's research in the Physical Laboratory here, under Dr. Wood, after
which he will probably return to
South Africa.
Dr. Voss brought his wife with
him, and she will also spend the
winter here. The difference in seasons makes it possible for Dr. Voss
to come here, for the Transvaal
University College has just closed
for the summer vacation.
